Situation1: A minor misunderstanding about weekend plans just arose.
Expectation2: Wash and condition clients' hair before cutting or styling
Situation2: Heavy product buildup is causing tight tangles that will impede scissors.
Story: I glanced at my phone between clients and saw Mia’s text: “I thought we were going to your mom’s this weekend, not mine?” My heart sank. She sounded upset, and I knew I should call her right away, talk it through, and smooth things over before it grew into something bigger. That’s what a good boyfriend does—he listens, resolves, reassures. But right now, Mrs. Patel was in my chair, her hair thick with product, the tangles stubborn and tight. I could already feel the resistance my scissors would meet if I didn’t take the time to wash and condition her hair properly. She expected me to be thorough, gentle, and professional. I could see her watching me in the mirror, waiting for me to start. My phone buzzed again. I felt the pressure mounting—Mia needed me, but so did Mrs. Patel. I stood there, comb in hand, torn between the person I loved and the job I took pride in, wishing I could split myself in two.
